summary: “Is the girl ready? To give up her ears, her nose, her tongue? Her hopes and dreams, her loves and hates, all that makes a girl...
body:
“Is the girl ready? To give up her ears, her nose, her tongue? Her hopes and dreams, her loves and hates, all that makes a girl who she is, forever?

No, a girl is not ready to become no one. But she is ready to become someone else.”

reblog.comment:
“Is the girl ready? To give up her ears, her nose, her tongue? Her hopes and dreams, her loves and hates, all that makes a girl who she is, forever?

No, a girl is not ready to become no one. But she is ready to become someone else.”

trail.content_raw:
“Is the girl ready? To give up her ears, her nose, her tongue? Her hopes and dreams, her loves and hates, all that makes a girl who she is, forever?

No, a girl is not ready to become no one. But she is ready to become someone else.”

“Is the girl ready? To give up her ears, her nose, her tongue? Her hopes and dreams, her loves and hates, all that makes a girl who she is, forever?

No, a girl is not ready to become no one. But she is ready to become someone else.”

tags: but my biggest fear is that this is what the show does
since d&d and cogman hate arya
we'll have to wait and see
even if they do i will never accept it as arya's true endgame tho
summary: what really gets me about the arya leaves westeros in the end “theories” is that arya literally already tried that. she...
body:
what really gets me about the arya leaves westeros in the end “theories” is that arya literally already tried that. she dramatically left westeros behind. she thought there was nothing left for her there but ghosts and ruins and pain and hunger. so she left her entire world and everything she knew - her home, her pack, her language, her culture, her faith. most were lost to her anyway or so she believed. so arya plunged herself into the unknown. (but the opportunity to return to westeros - to jon - to her home is never far from her mind) she went to a foreign city on a different continent where she’s trying to let go of the past. the kindly man even offers her a life outside the house of black and white - she could marry, get a job, ect. the entire world is open to her. if she wanted arya could board a ship, explore and never look back.

but she can’t let arya stark go. in grrm’s own words “she cant quite give [needle] up” so why??? when given back her pack and her home and her name would she decide to leave westeros……again? even when arya thought she had lost everything she was unable to truly let go

after arya heard winterfell had been burned she first considers flying away; up past the stars and the moon to parts unknown. its then the old gods remind her: “the lone wolf dies but the pack survives” “You are Arya of Winterfell, daughter of the north.” and arya herself understands. thats who she is and thats where she belongs.

blog.name: nobodysuspectsthebutterfly
blog.title: Nobody ever suspects the butterfly...
blog.description:
Hey, you can call me Mindset, or Butterfly.
I like: Comics, ASOIAF, music, art, books, sf & fantasy, butterflies, birds, pretty rocks, and many other things. See my sidebar tags and links for more details.
I help mod: ASOIAF University and A Song of Theories.
Note to ASOIAF fandom followers: I've read all the books, and rarely if ever cut for spoilers, sorry. Please check my FAQ and the other links on my sidebar for more info.

tags: seriously HUGE notp one of the hugest
wolf and dog roadtrip of doom
summary: So . . . what do dogs do to wolves?
question: So . . . what do dogs do to wolves?
answer:
Hunt them down and kill them, from the context. Though wolves fight back.

Though there are more, um, racy interpretations of that line, in a lot of sansan fics. Because, y’know, because. Such an interpretation probably exists in S/A fics as well, because, but that is a huge notp for me, so I would rather not know so please nobody tell me.

Hunt them down and kill them, from the context. Though wolves fight back.

blog.name: too-much-jonerys
blog.title: Jonerys Side Blog
blog.description:
Main Blog: lareinadecorazones.tumblr.com

Ao3: ReinaWritesStuff

CURRENTLY A GAME OF THRONES SEASON 8 NEGATIVITY BLOG. This is my Jonerys side blog, so my shipping fuckery doesn't disrupt my non-shipper/GoT followers because Jonerys is my life force now. I want to post and reblog in peace. NOTE: This blog is Gendarya, Team Dragonstone-friendly. This blog is NOT J*nsa-friendly or supportive of Jon or Dany's past romantic pairings. I don't actively hate on them on here in public. But, I will not post anything about them either.

summary:
Howling ghosts they reappear 
In mountains that are stacked with fear.
But, you're a king, and I'm a lionheart.
****
And, as the...
body:
Howling ghosts they reappear

In mountains that are stacked with fear.

But, you’re a king, and I’m a lionheart.

****

And, as the world comes to an end,

I’ll be here to hold your hand.

Cause you’re my king, and I’m your lionheart.

“King and Lionheart”- Of Monsters and Men


Have this shitty edit to commemorate the siblings bond that D&D can pry from my cold, dead fingers. In this house, the Starklings love and support each other and this song is them.

summary:
Arya : You sent her to kill me !
Jaqen : Now, I'm not one to get into the feels, usually, but... you seem genuinely distressed....
body:
Arya : You sent her to kill me !
Jaqen : Now, I'm not one to get into the feels, usually, but... you seem genuinely distressed. You okay? Do you want to--I don't know--chat about it or something? Sex is always on the table.

summary: She sang for mercy, for the living and the dead alike, for Bran and Rickon and Robb, for her sister Arya and her bastard brother...
caption:
She sang for mercy, for the living and the dead alike, for Bran and Rickon and Robb, for her sister Arya and her bastard brother Jon Snow, away off on the Wall.

- Sansa V, Clash of Kings

summary: I’m rereading Arya, Jon, and Dany’s chapters for reasons and strangely enough, they pair well together. The loneliness and...
body:
I’m rereading Arya, Jon, and Dany’s chapters for reasons and strangely enough, they pair well together. The loneliness and isolation Jon and Arya initially feel as they struggle to adjust to their new homes must have been intended to mirror each other.

They both start out in their new environments feeling betrayed by their loved ones. When Jon sees that the Night’s Watch has been reduced to a repository for criminals and rejects rather than a group of honorable protectors, he realizes his father and uncle must have known and chose not to warn him. 

“No one had told him the Night’s Watch would be like this; no one except Tyrion Lannister. The dwarf had given him the truth on the road north, but by then it had been too late. Jon wondered if his father had known what the Wall would be like. He must have, he thought; that only made it hurt the worse.

Even his uncle had abandoned him in this cold place at the end of the world. Up here, the genial Benjen Stark he had known became a different person. He was First Ranger, and he spent his days and nights with Lord Commander Mormont and Maester Aemon and the other high officers, while Jon was given over to the less than tender charge of Ser Alliser Thorne.”

Meanwhile, Arya sees that the rules of justice and heroism she was taught were nothing but hollow words, which damages the trust and faith she had in her father and the household guards she thought of as friends:

“This was the first time they had supped with the men since arriving in King’s Landing. Arya hated it. She hated the sounds of their voices now, the way they laughed, the stories they told. They’d been her friends, she’d felt safe around them, but now she knew that was a lie. They’d let the queen kill Lady, that was horrible enough, but then the Hound found Mycah. Jeyne Poole had told Arya that he’d cut him up in so many pieces that they’d given him back to the butcher in a bag, and at first the poor man had thought it was a pig they’d slaughtered. And no one had raised a voice or drawn a blade or anything, not Harwin who always talked so bold, or Alyn who was going to be a knight, or Jory who was captain of the guard. Not even her father.”

Both Jon and Arya are forced to let go of part of their childhood ideals and see the harsher realities of their world. Unfortunately, that includes realizing that their father isn’t perfect. This, in addition to other factors, leads to both of them feeling isolated without anyone to fully trust:

“Jon followed the rest back to the armory, walking alone. He often walked alone here. There were almost twenty in the group he trained with, yet not one he could call a friend.”

“If he must be alone, he would make solitude his armor.”

“No one talked to Arya. She didn’t care. She liked it that way. She would have eaten her meals alone in her bedchamber if they let her.”

“She found herself wishing that Jon was here with her now. Then maybe she wouldn’t feel so alone.”

Their longing for each other and their brothers are even similar:

“That was when Arya missed her brothers most. She wanted to tease Bran and play with baby Rickon and have Robb smile at her. She wanted Jon to muss up her hair and call her “little sister” and finish her sentences with her.”

“He missed his true brothers: little Rickon, bright eyes shining as he begged for a sweet; Robb, his rival and best friend and constant companion; Bran, stubborn and curious, always wanting to follow and join in whatever Jon and Robb were doing. … And Arya … he missed her even more than Robb, skinny little thing that she was, all scraped knees and tangled hair and torn clothes, so fierce and willful. Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had … yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.”

They also have similar nightmares with Arya running around the Red Keep looking for Ned while Jon’s dreams take him to an empty Winterfell looking for his family.

It’s also interesting that they’re able to find happiness in their new situations through arms training. Arya gains a new dancing instructor who fits her unique style while Jon becomes an instructor himself, rather than bullying the other recruits. They’re both able to gain genuine confidence while building new relationships.

reblog.comment:
I’m rereading Arya, Jon, and Dany’s chapters for reasons and strangely enough, they pair well together. The loneliness and isolation Jon and Arya initially feel as they struggle to adjust to their new homes must have been intended to mirror each other.

They both start out in their new environments feeling betrayed by their loved ones. When Jon sees that the Night’s Watch has been reduced to a repository for criminals and rejects rather than a group of honorable protectors, he realizes his father and uncle must have known and chose not to warn him. 

“No one had told him the Night’s Watch would be like this; no one except Tyrion Lannister. The dwarf had given him the truth on the road north, but by then it had been too late. Jon wondered if his father had known what the Wall would be like. He must have, he thought; that only made it hurt the worse.

Even his uncle had abandoned him in this cold place at the end of the world. Up here, the genial Benjen Stark he had known became a different person. He was First Ranger, and he spent his days and nights with Lord Commander Mormont and Maester Aemon and the other high officers, while Jon was given over to the less than tender charge of Ser Alliser Thorne.”

Meanwhile, Arya sees that the rules of justice and heroism she was taught were nothing but hollow words, which damages the trust and faith she had in her father and the household guards she thought of as friends:

“This was the first time they had supped with the men since arriving in King’s Landing. Arya hated it. She hated the sounds of their voices now, the way they laughed, the stories they told. They’d been her friends, she’d felt safe around them, but now she knew that was a lie. They’d let the queen kill Lady, that was horrible enough, but then the Hound found Mycah. Jeyne Poole had told Arya that he’d cut him up in so many pieces that they’d given him back to the butcher in a bag, and at first the poor man had thought it was a pig they’d slaughtered. And no one had raised a voice or drawn a blade or anything, not Harwin who always talked so bold, or Alyn who was going to be a knight, or Jory who was captain of the guard. Not even her father.”

Both Jon and Arya are forced to let go of part of their childhood ideals and see the harsher realities of their world. Unfortunately, that includes realizing that their father isn’t perfect. This, in addition to other factors, leads to both of them feeling isolated without anyone to fully trust:

“Jon followed the rest back to the armory, walking alone. He often walked alone here. There were almost twenty in the group he trained with, yet not one he could call a friend.”

“If he must be alone, he would make solitude his armor.”

“No one talked to Arya. She didn’t care. She liked it that way. She would have eaten her meals alone in her bedchamber if they let her.”

“She found herself wishing that Jon was here with her now. Then maybe she wouldn’t feel so alone.”

Their longing for each other and their brothers are even similar:

“That was when Arya missed her brothers most. She wanted to tease Bran and play with baby Rickon and have Robb smile at her. She wanted Jon to muss up her hair and call her “little sister” and finish her sentences with her.”

“He missed his true brothers: little Rickon, bright eyes shining as he begged for a sweet; Robb, his rival and best friend and constant companion; Bran, stubborn and curious, always wanting to follow and join in whatever Jon and Robb were doing. … And Arya … he missed her even more than Robb, skinny little thing that she was, all scraped knees and tangled hair and torn clothes, so fierce and willful. Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had … yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.”

They also have similar nightmares with Arya running around the Red Keep looking for Ned while Jon’s dreams take him to an empty Winterfell looking for his family.

It’s also interesting that they’re able to find happiness in their new situations through arms training. Arya gains a new dancing instructor who fits her unique style while Jon becomes an instructor himself, rather than bullying the other recruits. They’re both able to gain genuine confidence while building new relationships.

Their longing for each other and their brothers are even similar:

“That was when Arya missed her brothers most. She wanted to tease Bran and play with baby Rickon and have Robb smile at her. She wanted Jon to muss up her hair and call her “little sister” and finish her sentences with her.”

“He missed his true brothers: little Rickon, bright eyes shining as he begged for a sweet; Robb, his rival and best friend and constant companion; Bran, stubborn and curious, always wanting to follow and join in whatever Jon and Robb were doing. … And Arya … he missed her even more than Robb, skinny little thing that she was, all scraped knees and tangled hair and torn clothes, so fierce and willful. Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had … yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.”

They also have similar nightmares with Arya running around the Red Keep looking for Ned while Jon’s dreams take him to an empty Winterfell looking for his family.

It’s also interesting that they’re able to find happiness in their new situations through arms training. Arya gains a new dancing instructor who fits her unique style while Jon becomes an instructor himself, rather than bullying the other recruits. They’re both able to gain genuine confidence while building new relationships.

summary: Inktober 9: Precious I loved the interaction between Arya and Lady Smallwood in A Storm of Swords. It was so pure, with Lady...
caption:
Inktober 9: Precious

I loved the interaction between Arya and Lady Smallwood in A Storm of Swords. It was so pure, with Lady Smallwood wishing to keep Arya safe with her.


“I do not know who you are, child,” the woman said, “and it may be that’s for the best. Someone important, I fear.” She smoothed down Arya’s collar. “In times like these, it is better to be insignificant. Would that I could keep you here with me. That would not be safe, though. I have walls, but too few men to hold them.” She sighed.

…

“I’m sorry, my lady.” Arya suddenly felt bad for her, and ashamed. “I’m sorry I tore the acorn dress too. It was pretty.”

“Yes, child. And so are you. Be brave.”

summary: Here's a silly ask for you! ;) If your favourite Game of Thrones characters were different types of cheeses, which kinds would...
question: Here's a silly ask for you! ;) If your favourite Game of Thrones characters were different types of cheeses, which kinds would they be?
answer:
LMFAO, best ask ever. Okay, this is just pure association:

  • Arya: Gouda
  • Cersei: Feta
  • Daenerys: Taleggio
  • Jaime: Cheddar
  • Jon: Edam
  • Tyrion: Parmesan

  • Tyrion: Parmesan

summary: So, given Maisie says Arya ends the series alone, and in season 6 Arya asked “What is west of Westeros?” I am pretty sure this...
body:
So, given Maisie says Arya ends the series alone, and in season 6 Arya asked “What is west of Westeros?” I am pretty sure this is how her story will end.

Arya announces her intention to sail across the Sunset Sea, assuring that she will be back someday. She has happy-tender goodbyes with her family and Gendry (in the show they will probably kiss, in the book there might be some light flirting). While she is sailing away, however, we linger on a shot of her looking rather sad. Or its reversed with sad-tender goodbyes and a shot of her looking excited for her next adventure. Either way, it will be ambiguous and people will be asking, “But does she come back?” until the end of time.

blog.name: gendrie
blog.title: fierce and terrible and hers
blog.description:
annalesa / 27 / pisces /
they would not make her yield

title: arya/gendry + ice and fire
body:
NORTH / SOUTH

“You are Arya of Winterfell, daughter of the north. You told me you could be strong. You have the wolf blood in you.”

“You have black hair and blue eyes, and you were born in the shadow of the Red Keep. Has no one ever remarked upon your face?”

OLD GODS / R’HLLOR

The old gods of the north must have been guiding her steps.

“Is there some other god he loves?” asked Hyle Hunt. / “The Lord of Light,”

STRENGTH AND SPEED

“You don’t know how strong I am.”
“You don’t know how quick I am.”

LUNAR ANIMAL / SOLAR ANIMAL

And dreamed. That was the best part, the dreaming. She dreamed of wolves most every night.

“A smart boy, but stubborn. That helm … the others call him bullheaded, so he threw it in their teeth." 

SMOL AND TOL

She felt so tiny in his arms, nothing but a scrawny little girl.

The master called over a tall lad about Robb’s age, his arms and chest corded with muscle.

OFFENSIVE WEAPON / DEFENSIVE ARMOR 

Sleep did not come easy, so she borrowed Yoren’s stone and set to honing Needle.

Then he’d go off to polish his helm. It was a beautiful helm, rounded and curved, with a slit visor and two great metal bull’s horns. 

GIRL / BOY

 ”I’m a girl,“ Arya said, exasperated.

"You’re the eunuch.” / “You know I’m not.” Gendry smiled. “You want me to take out my cock and prove it? I don’t have anything to hide.”

HIGHBORN / LOWBORN

“You play at being a servant, but in your heart you are a lord’s daughter. You have taken other names, but you wore them as lightly as you might wear a gown. Under them was always Arya.”

“That’s right,” he said angrily. “I’m too bloody lowborn to be kin to m'lady high.”
